description: From Middle English comparable, from Middle French comparable, from Latin comparƒÅbilis.

adjectives.description: comparable (comparative more comparable, superlative most comparable)

entries.meaning: (often with to) Able to be compared (to).
examples: An elephant is comparable in size to a double-decker bus.
You can't say that robbing a bank is like pickpocketing. The two are just not comparable.

entries.meaning: (mathematics) Constituting a pair in a particular partial order.
examples: Six and forty-two are comparable in the divides order, but six and nine are not.

entries.meaning: (grammar) Said of an adjective that has comparative and superlative forms.
examples: "Big" is a comparable adjective, since it can take the forms "bigger" and "biggest"; but "unique" is not comparable, except in disputed, but common, usage.
